rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.

<!--[[Image:LifePosterCover.jpg|thumb|''[[Life Magazine]]'' issue documenting psychedelic poster art phenomenon. Cover features art by [[Rick Griffin]], [[Wes Wilson]], [[Warren Dayton]] [[Victor Moscoso]], etc. September, 1967 {{deletable image-caption|Saturday, December 18, 2010|date=December 2010}}]]-->
<!--[[Image:LifePosterCover.jpg|thumb|''[[Life Magazine]]'' issue documenting psychedelic poster art phenomenon. Cover features art by [[Rick Griffin]], [[Wes Wilson]], [[Warren Dayton]] [[Victor Moscoso]], etc. September, 1967 {{deletable image-caption|Saturday, December 18, 2010|date=December 2010}}]]-->
'''Psychedelic art''' is any kind of [[visual artwork]] inspired by [[psychedelic experiences]] induced by drugs such as [[lysergic acid diethylamide|LSD]], [[mescaline]], and [[psilocybin]]. The word "psychedelic" (coined by British psychologist [[Humphry Osmond]]) "mind manifesting". By that definition all artistic efforts to depict the inner world of the psyche may be considered "psychedelic". In common parlance "Psychedelic Art" refers above all to the art movement of the [[Counterculture of the 1960s|1960s counterculture]]. Psychedelic visual arts were a counterpart to [[psychedelic rock|psychedelic rock music]]. Concert posters, album covers, lightshows, murals, comic books, underground newspapers and more reflected not only the kaleidoscopically swirling patterns of LSD hallucinations, but also revolutionary political, social and spiritual sentiments inspired by insights derived from these psychedelic states of consciousness.
'''Psychedelic art''' is any kind of [[visual artwork]] inspired by [[psychedelic experiences]] induced by drugs such as [[lysergic acid diethylamide|LSD]], [[mescaline]], and [[psilocybin]]. The word "psychedelic" (coined by British psychologist [[Humphry Osmond]]) "mind manifesting". By that definition all artistic efforts to depict the inner world of the psyche may be considered "psychedelic". In common parlance "Psychedelic Art" refers above all to the art movement of the [[Counterculture of the 1960s|1960s counterculture]]. Psychedelic visual arts were a counterpart to [[psychedelic rock|psychedelic rock music]]. Concert posters, album covers, lightshows, murals, comic books, underground newspapers and more reflected not only the kaleidoscopically swirling patterns of LSD hallucinations, but also revolutionary political, social and spiritual sentiments inspired by insights derived from these psychedelic states of consciousness.
